Title: Wee earthquake, one of many, wiggles French Gulch Friday morning
Body: Geologists reported aÂ small earthquake shook an area west of Redding on Friday morning.  While 2.4 is a bit stronger than most North State earthquakes, it's considered quite small, according toÂ USGSÂ earthquake geologist Alex Hatem.Â  Wee quakes areÂ common in the North State, she said.Â "You (Shasta and Siskiyou counties)Â are in a volcanic area,Â whichÂ can be prone to having small earthquakes." According to the USGS, there have been about a dozenÂ tremors recorded by the USGSÂ since Aug. 11 in theÂ area stretching from Red Bluff to Mount ShastaÂ and from Hayfork to Lassen Peak. Other than the one recorded near French Gulch, none had a magnitudeÂ over 1.8.Â  A 2.4 earthquake is usually hard to feel unless you are in bed close to the epicenter, being very still, Hatem said. "Walking around, you probably would not have felt it." A post on Facebook asked ifÂ anyone felt the earthquake. As of 11 a.m. Friday, no one reported knowing it had happened. The USGS recommends people getÂ under a table and cover their head if they feel an earthquake, Hatem said.  This week, the USGS launched a Twitter account for people to track earthquakes, said Paul Laustsen, public affairs specialist at the USGSâ€™ Earthquake Science Center. Go to @USGS_Quakes to follow.  Jessica Skropanic is features reporter for the Record Searchlight/USA Today Network.Â She covers lifestyle andÂ entertainment stories, andÂ weekly arts featureÂ d.a.t.e.Â  FollowÂ her on TwitterÂ @RS_JSkropanicÂ and onÂ Facebook. Join Jessica in theÂ Get Out! Nor CalÂ recreation Facebook group. To support and sustain this work,Â please subscribe today. Thank you.

Title: Memphis university sends researchers to study NC earthquake
Body: SPARTA, N.C. â€” The University of Memphis says specialists from its earthquake research center are traveling to North Carolina to monitor aftershocks of this past weekendâ€™s 5.1 magnitude earthquake.Â  The most powerful earthquake to hit North Carolina in more than 100 years struck Sunday morning. There were no reports of serious injuries, but some minor structural damage was reported in Sparta, as well as cracks in roads.Â  The University of Memphisâ€™ Center for Earthquake Research and Information, with help from North Carolina and U.S. geological survey officials, has deployed four portable seismograph stations in a tightly controlled pattern to record aftershocks of the earthquake.Â  Next up in 5 Example video title will go here for this video     In Other News Notifications can be turned off anytime in the browser settings.

Title: There was a 'boomerang earthquake' in 2016. Here's what that means
Body: A â€˜boomerang earthquakeâ€™ hit the Atlantic Ocean. Hereâ€™s what it means Adobe Stock  Earthquakes can apparently turn around and hit an area with a second pass â€” an event known as a â€œboomerang earthquakeâ€ â€” in rare circumstances.  Scientists recently found evidence of the â€œboomerang earthquakeâ€ in a new study, highlighting an event that happened in the Atlantic Ocean back in 2016. The earthquake â€” which took place at the Romanche fracture zone â€” happened between Brazil and the west coast of Africa. There was a 7.1 magnitude earthquake in August 2016. The tremor traveled one direction and then it came back around for a second strike, bringing an increase of speed on the second strike, according to ScienceAlert. Or, described another way, â€œtheÂ ruptureÂ initially spreads away from initial break but then turns and runs back the other way at higher speeds,â€ according to Phys.org. â€œWhilst scientists have found that such a reversing rupture mechanism is possible from theoretical models, our new study provides some of the clearest evidence for this enigmatic mechanism occurring in a real fault,â€Â said Stephen Hicks, lead researcher and seismologist from Imperial College London.  â€œEven though the fault structure seems simple, the way the earthquake grew was not, and this was completely opposite to how we expected the earthquake to look before we started to analyze the data.â€ The earthquake had two phases. The first traveled eastward before coming back around and going westward.  This, of course, is the first reported incident of a boomerang earthquake. Itâ€™s so rare that itâ€™s unlikely to find one again unless researchers seek it out, according to National Geographic. Evidence is growing of these events. But more research is needed to discover more. â€œThe theory says that itâ€™s there, but itâ€™s quite difficult to see that (in the real world),â€ said geophysicistÂ Louisa Brotherson, a Ph.D. researcher at the University of Liverpool in the U.K., who simulates earthquakes. Copyright Â© 2023 Deseret News Publishing Company. All Rights Reserved

Title: Do you need earthquake insurance?
Body: Next up in 5 Example video title will go here for this video     GREENSBORO, N.C. â€” â€œWe started last week with a hurricane and we ended the week with an earthquake. I don't think people have a clue as to what is not in their insurance policy,â€ said Christopher Cook with Alliance Insurance Services. What is not in your standard homeowners insurance policy? Flooding, earthquake damage, and wind damage. For example, damage from Sundayâ€™s earthquake would not be covered unless the homeowner had earthquake coverage. Most folks donâ€™t have this extra coverage. Cook says only two of his 4,000 customers have earthquake coverage. And right now, even if you had the money to buy coverage, you canâ€™t get it. â€œWe've already had companies come out to us and say do not issue insurance for seven days, they need to see what is going to happen before there are policies issued. Then there is a two-week waiting period before we do that. You have to be cognizant that if the ground is still shaking, companies aren't going to let you add coverage," added Cook.Â   Cook says it's worth having your insurance agent run the numbers for you-- so you can decide if you think the risk is worth it. Much like earthquake insurance, you canâ€™t get flood insurance right before a storm is coming. Christopher Cook said, "I get this question all the time, it starts like, â€˜Hey there is a massive storm in the Bahamas and it looks like it is coming to us. I need to add flood insuranceâ€™. My answer is, â€˜I'll be happy to add flood insurance for you, today is August 10, you'll have coverage September 11â€™.â€ There is a 30 day waiting period for flood coverage to go into effect. Even if you donâ€™t think you need earthquake or flood coverage, if you haven't really looked at it in a couple of years, you should and ask your insurance agent questions, because you might think you're covered when you're not. â€œInsurance pays for things that were sudden and accidental by nature but if you've had a leak in your shower for five years and now you have mold in your wall and your subfloor is collapsing into your crawl space, that happened over a long, long, long period of time, it wasnâ€™t sudden and accidental, your insurance company is not going to pay for it," said Cook.Â  Your hot water heater isnâ€™t working anymore. Doesnâ€™t your policy pay for that? Christopher Cook explained a common misconception. â€œSomething that is common that people reach out to us about is maintenance items. If your hot water heater is 20 years old and it fails, it was built to last 20 years. It's part of homeownership, it stinks but your insurance doesnâ€™t cover mechanical failures of systems in your home.â€ Notifications can be turned off anytime in the browser settings.

Title: Sunday's Bible reading described a powerful earthquake. Then the ground shook in NC
Body: CHARLOTTE, N.C. (WBTV) - It was time for the first reading at Sundayâ€™s 8 a.m. outdoor Mass that St. Gabriel Catholic Church in Charlotte has been holding during the pandemic.  After the wind there was an earthquake â€” but the LORD was not in the earthquake. After the earthquake there was fire â€” but the LORD was not in the fire. After the fire there was a tiny whispering sound. Father Richard Sutter, pastor at St. Gabriel near SouthPark, said as the reader got to the earthquake verses, several attendees felt the ground shake.  While he didnâ€™t feel it himself, Sutter said parishioners came up to him as soon as the service ended. Some may call it a coincidence â€” or â€œGod-incidenceâ€ as Sutter put it â€” but the priest said the jarring moment can be a lesson for this time. â€œWhen thereâ€™s fear from an earthquake, when thereâ€™s fear from a storm, when thereâ€™s fear from a pandemic and uncertainty... you have to let the Lord speak to us the truth,â€ he said. In fact, Catholics around the globe read the same passage from 1 Kings that weekend, planned well in advance of Sundayâ€™s quake. â€˜A GOOD MESSAGEâ€™ Closer to the epicenter, Father Cory Catron was preparing for another Sunday of services since becoming pastor for churches in Sparta and nearby Jefferson in late July. He was in Jefferson, about 25 miles from Sparta, when the church doors and windows shook. It made for â€œgood homily material,â€ he said with a laugh, the levity possible because the church was unscathed and parishioners reported only minor property damage.  â€œThe ceiling creaked for like three seconds, and everybody kind of looked up and immediately we knew what it was,â€ he said. Catron said the timely passage from scripture teaches that in this time of pandemics, financial worry and natural disasters, to slow down. â€œGod is found in the stillness and God is found in the silence,â€ he said. â€œWe have to cultivate that silence, which is a very difficult thing to do. â€œItâ€™s a good message that it doesnâ€™t matter how how strange and messed up and scary everything can be, that God is still present to us.â€ Copyright 2020 The Charlotte Observer. All rights reserved.

Title: 5.1 Magnitude Earthquake Strikes North Carolina
Body: Please enable JS and disable any ad blocker

Title: 5.1 magnitude earthquake rattles Virginia, North Carolina
Body: Menu RICHMOND, Va. -- A 5.1 magnitude earthquake rattled parts of Virginia and North Carolina Sunday morning. There have been no immediate reports of damage, nor injuries.  Sunday's earthquake is one of the biggest to impact Virginia since the 5.8-magnitude earthquake centered in Mineral, Virginia on August 23, 2011. And the largest earthquake in North Carolina since a 5.2 earthquake in 1916. "According to the U.S. Geological Survey database, the 5.1 magnitude earthquake near Sparta this morning is the second strongest earthquake to occur in North Carolina 1900," the National Weather Service Greenville-Spartanburg Office wrote on Twitter. "The strongest was a 5.2 magnitude earthquake near Skyland, North Carolina in February 1916." The 5.1 magnitude earthquake was preceded by multiple, smaller "foreshocks" on Saturday. Multiple aftershocks are expected over the next few weeks. The USGS forecasted a 4 percent chance of one or more aftershocks that are larger than magnitude 5.1. This story originally reported by Mike Stone on wtvr.com. About WMAR

Title: 5.1 magnitude earthquake hits North Carolina, most powerful in the state since 1916
Body: Profile Sections tv Featured More From NBC Follow NBC News A magnitude 5.1 earthquake was felt on Sunday morning near Sparta, North Carolina, according to the U.S. Geological Survey.  In 1916, the region experienced another 5.1 magnitude earthquake â€” the largest reported in the area, according to a U.S. Geological Survey tweet, which now ties Sunday morning's quake in intensity. The epicenter was approximately 37 miles from Boone, North Carolina, and 46 miles from Lenoir, North Carolina, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. Approximately 45,000 people have reported feeling the quake as of just before 10 a.m. ET. Early reports did not indicate any major injuries or widespread damage, according to NBC News affiliate WCNC. I think I just felt an earthquake in Raleigh. Just another day in 2020 #earthquake #nc #ncearthquake pic.twitter.com/pzl7iGJW9M definitely didnâ€™t have â€œearthquake in Raleigh, NCâ€ on my 2020 bingo card pic.twitter.com/2btjnn54jw On Twitter, "earthquake," "NCEarthquake," and "5.1 magnitude," were all trending as of Sunday morning. The earthquake could potentially produce aftershocks, according to the U.S. Geological Survey. â€œThe USGS advises everyone to be aware of the possibility of aftershocks, especially when in or around vulnerable structures such as unreinforced masonry buildings,â€ its website reads. Kalhan Rosenblatt is a reporter covering youth and internet culture for NBC News, based in New York. Â©Â 2023 NBC UNIVERSAL

Title: 5.1 magnitude earthquake reported near North Carolina-Virginia border
Body: The earthquake was recorded in Sparta, North Carolina. A 5.1 magnitude earthquake struck near the border between North Carolina and Virginia on Sunday morning.  There are no reports of damage or injuries. The tremors were felt from Virginia to South Carolina. 24/7 coverage of breaking news and live events

Title: 5.1 magnitude earthquake felt across North Carolina
Body: WAVY.com Please enter a search term. Please enter a search term. Courtesy â€“ WGHP    Courtesy â€“ WGHP    SPARTA, N.C. (AP) â€” The most powerful earthquake to hit North Carolina in more than 100 years shook much of the state early Sunday, rattling homes, businesses and residents.  There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries. Michael Hull was standing in his driveway at his home in Sparta when he noticed a group of deer running. â€œNot even a minute passed and the side-to-side motion started,â€ Hull said. â€œIt takes you a minute to realize whatâ€™s happening, and you just canâ€™t believe it. Then it was over. It was loud, like God was shaking a mountain at you, literally.â€ Karen Backer was in her Greensboro apartment when she heard initially mistook banging in her kitchen for her roommate. â€œNope, it was the cabinet doors â€˜clinkingâ€™ open and closed! My neighbors on the other hand said they felt our apartment building shaking,â€ Backer said. â€œWell, sadly, nothing surprises me in 2020, but a hurricane and an earthquake in the same week is crazy.â€ It was the largest earthquake to hit the state since 1916, when a magnitude 5.5 quake occurred near Skyland, the weather service said. The U.S. Geological Service said the quakeâ€™s epicenter was about 2.5 miles (four kilometers) southeast of Sparta, just south of the Virginia-North Carolina border. The USGS said the population in the affected region resides in structures â€œthat are resistant to earthquake shaking, though vulnerable structures exist.â€ The quake was felt in nearby states including Virginia, South Carolina and Tennessee. According to the @USGS database, the 5.1 magnitude earthquake near Sparta, NC this morning is the second strongest earthquake to occur in NC since 1900. The strongest was a 5.2 magntitude earthquake near Skyland, NC in February 1916. #ncwx #scwx #gawx By far the largest quake in North Carolina since a M 5.2 in 1916. #Earthquake pic.twitter.com/J3yuTrdSq5 Developingâ€¦ Copyright 2023 Nexstar Media Inc. Title: Kelly Clarkson, Lil Nas X, Marshmello and More React to 4.2 Magnitude Earthquake in L.A.
Body:
A 4.2 magnitude earthquake shook up California's San Fernando Valley on Thursday morning (July 30), and celebs from Kelly Clarkson to Lil Nas X were feeling the earth move all the way in Losâ€¦ 
													By
												

	Glenn Rowley
 A 4.2 magnitude earthquake shook up Californiaâ€™s San Fernando Valley on Thursday morning (July 30), and celebs from Kelly Clarkson to Lil Nas X were feeling the earth move all the way in Los Angeles. â€œMy children are in my arms and we are awake too early because of that earthquake but now theyâ€™re discussing how their ninja skills would totally help in this time,â€ Clarkson tweeted.Â â€œIâ€™m just happy theyâ€™re more interested and curious about it and less scared. Hallelujah!â€

 Meanwhile, artists like JoJo and Marshmello offered more sardonic takes on the scary rumbling in the Valley. â€œMy preparedness for an earthquake is the same as the US government for COVID-19. None,â€ the big-voiced pop singer wrote, while the helmeted DJ tweeted, â€œIf that #earthquake is any clue of whatâ€™s next in 2020, Iâ€™m done.â€ Check out the best reactions to this morningâ€™s earthquake below. god after creating that earthquake pic.twitter.com/m0R2Fa3dRU â€” MONTERO ğŸ¦‹ (@LilNasX) July 30, 2020   â€” Kelly Clarkson (@kellyclarkson) July 30, 2020  Happy to know that was an earthquake cuz just I woke up confused af â€” TINASHE Â³Â³Â³ (@Tinashe) July 30, 2020  My preparedness for an earthquake is the same as the US government for COVID-19. Title: Powerful earthquake jolts parts of Alaska, leads to tsunami warning
Body:
Fox 59 Please enter a search term. Please enter a search term.     ANCHORAGE, Alaska (AP) â€” A powerful earthquake off Alaskaâ€™s southern coast jolted coastal communities late Tuesday, and some residents briefly scrambled for higher ground over fears of a tsunami. There were no immediate reports of damage in the sparsely populated area of the state, and the tsunami warning was canceled after the magnitude 7.8 quake off the Alaska Peninsula produced a wave of a less than a foot.  Because of the temblorâ€™s location, nearby communities along the Alaska Peninsula did not experience shaking that would normally be associated with that magnitude of a quake, said Michael West, Alaska State Seismologist. That doesnâ€™t mean they slept through it, West said residents in small towns within a hundred miles (160 kilometers) of the quake reported very strong shaking. Some shaking was also felt more than 500 miles (805 kilometers) away in the Anchorage area, West said. â€œNo reports of any damage,â€ Kodiak Police Sgt. Mike Sorter said early Wednesday morning. â€œNo injuries were reported. Everything is nominal.â€ Kodiak is about 200 miles (320 kilometers) northeast of where the earthquake was centered. The tsunami warning prompted coastal residents to evacuate to higher ground, with social media posts showing long lines of people fleeing towns like Homer and Kodiak as tsunami sirens wailed in the background. On Kodiak Island, the local high school and Catholic opened their doors for evacuees, the Anchorage Daily News reported. â€œWeâ€™ve got a high school full of people,â€ said Larry LeDoux, superintendent of the Kodiak School District. â€œIâ€™ve been passing out masks since the first siren sounded,â€ he told the Daily News. â€œEverythingâ€™s as calm as can be. Weâ€™ve got probably 300, 400 people all wearing masks,â€ he said before the warning was canceled. Tsunami warnings are commonplace for people who grew up in Kodiak. â€Iâ€™ve been doing these since I was a little kid,â€ LeDoux told the newspaper. â€œOld news.â€ Officials at the National Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer, Alaska, began calling off tsunami advisories and warnings after a wave of less than 1 foot (30 centimeters) was recorded in the community of Sand Point. â€œI might have expected a little bit more water, but Iâ€™m happy that there wasnâ€™t,â€ said David Hale, the senior duty scientist at the tsunami center. Tuesdayâ€™s quake was more powerful than the magnitude 7.1 earthquake that caused damage in the Anchorage area in November 2018. â€œThis earthquake released about 15 times as much energy as that earthquake, said West, the state seismologist. More than a dozen aftershocks of magnitude 4.0 or higher were reported immediately after the earthquake, he said from the Alaska Earthquake Center at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. â€We got people here who are going be working all night,â€ West said early Wednesday morning. â€These aftershocks will go and go and go and go.â€ The Alaska-Aleutian Trench was also where a magnitude 9.2 quake in 1964 was centered. That remains the second most powerful earthquake ever recorded. The temblor and ensuing tsunami caused widespread damage and killed 131 people, some as far away as Oregon and California. Alaska is the most actively seismic state. Nearly 25,000 earthquakes have been recorded in Alaska since Jan. 1, according to the center.

Social media posts showed long lines of people fleeing towns like Homer and Kodiak while tsunami sirens wailed in the background. On Kodiak Island, the local high school opened its doors for evacuees, as did the local Catholic school, the Anchorage Daily News reported. â€œWeâ€™ve got a high school full of people,â€ said Larry LeDoux, superintendent of the Kodiak School District. â€œIâ€™ve been passing out masks since the first siren sounded,â€ he told the Daily News. â€œEverythingâ€™s as calm as can be. Weâ€™ve got probably 300, 400 people all wearing masks,â€ he said before the warning was canceled. Tsunami warnings are commonplace for people who grew up in Kodiak. â€Iâ€™ve been doing these since I was a little kid,â€ LeDoux told the newspaper. â€œOld news.â€ Officials at the National Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer, Alaska, began calling off tsunami advisories and warnings after a wave of only 25 centimeters (.8 foot) was recorded in the community of Sand Point. â€œI might have expected a little bit more water, but Iâ€™m happy that there wasnâ€™t,â€ said David Hale, the senior duty scientist at the tsunami center. Tuesdayâ€™s quake was more powerful than the magnitude 7.1 earthquake that caused damage in the Anchorage area in November 2018. â€œThis earthquake released about 15 times as much energy as that earthquake, said West, the state seismologist. More than a dozen aftershocks of magnitude 4.0 or higher were reported immediately after the earthquake, he said by telephone from the Alaska Earthquake Center at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. â€We got people here who are going be working all night,â€ West said early Wednesday morning. â€These aftershocks will go and go and go and go.â€ The Alaska-Aleutian Trench was also where a magnitude 9.2 quake in 1964 was centered. That remains the second most powerful earthquake ever recorded. The temblor and ensuing tsunami caused widespread damage and killed 131 people, some as far away as Oregon and California. Alaska is the most actively seismic state. Nearly 25,000 earthquakes have been recorded in Alaska since Jan. 1, according to the center. On Kodiak Island, the local high school opened its doors for evacuees, as did the local Catholic school, the Anchorage Daily News reported. â€œWeâ€™ve got a high school full of people,â€ said Larry LeDoux, superintendent of the Kodiak School District. â€œIâ€™ve been passing out masks since the first siren sounded,â€ he told the Daily News. â€œEverythingâ€™s as calm as can be. Weâ€™ve got probably 300, 400 people all wearing masks,â€ he said before the warning was canceled. Tsunami warnings are commonplace for people who grew up in Kodiak. â€Iâ€™ve been doing these since I was a little kid,â€ LeDoux told the newspaper. â€œOld news.â€ Officials at the National Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer, Alaska, began calling off tsunami advisories and warnings after a wave of only 25 centimeters (.8 foot) was recorded in the community of Sand Point. â€œI might have expected a little bit more water, but Iâ€™m happy that there wasnâ€™t,â€ said David Hale, the senior duty scientist at the tsunami center. Tuesdayâ€™s quake was more powerful than the magnitude 7.1 earthquake that caused damage in the Anchorage area in November 2018. â€œThis earthquake released about 15 times as much energy as that earthquake, said West, the state seismologist. More than a dozen aftershocks of magnitude 4.0 or higher were reported immediately after the earthquake, he said by telephone from the Alaska Earthquake Center at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. â€We got people here who are going be working all night,â€ West said early Wednesday morning. â€These aftershocks will go and go and go and go.â€ The Alaska-Aleutian Trench was also where a magnitude 9.2 quake in 1964 was centered. That remains the second most powerful earthquake ever recorded. The temblor and ensuing tsunami caused widespread damage and killed 131 people, some as far away as Oregon and California. Alaska is the most actively seismic state. Nearly 25,000 earthquakes have been recorded in Alaska since Jan. 1, according to the center. Title: 7.8 earthquake jolts Alaska isles, tsunami warning issued, called off
Body: A powerful earthquake off Alaskaâ€™s southern coast jolted coastal communities late Tuesday, and some residents briefly scrambled for higher ground over fears of a tsunami. ANCHORAGE, Alaska â€” A powerful earthquake off Alaskaâ€™s southern coast jolted coastal communities late Tuesday, and some residents briefly scrambled for higher ground over fears of a tsunami. There were no immediate reports of damage in the sparsely populated area of the state, and the tsunami warning was canceled after the magnitude 7.8 quake off the Alaska Peninsula produced a wave of a less than a foot.  Because of the temblorâ€™s location, nearby communities along the Alaska Peninsula did not experience shaking that would normally be associated with that magnitude of a quake, said Michael West, Alaska State Seismologist. That doesnâ€™t mean they slept through it, West said residents in small towns within a hundred miles (160 kilometers) of the quake reported very strong shaking. Some shaking was also felt more than 500 miles (805 kilometers) away in the Anchorage area, West said. â€œNo reports of any damage,â€ Kodiak Police Sgt. Mike Sorter said early Wednesday morning. â€œNo injuries were reported. Everything is nominal.â€ Kodiak is about 200 miles (320 kilometers) northeast of where the earthquake was centered. The tsunami warning prompted coastal residents to evacuate to higher ground, with social media posts showing long lines of people fleeing towns like Homer and Kodiak as tsunami sirens wailed in the background. On Kodiak Island, the local high school and Catholic opened their doors for evacuees, the Anchorage Daily News reported. â€œWeâ€™ve got a high school full of people,â€ said Larry LeDoux, superintendent of the Kodiak School District. â€œIâ€™ve been passing out masks since the first siren sounded,â€ he told the Daily News. â€œEverythingâ€™s as calm as can be. Weâ€™ve got probably 300, 400 people all wearing masks,â€ he said before the warning was canceled. Tsunami warnings are commonplace for people who grew up in Kodiak. â€Iâ€™ve been doing these since I was a little kid,â€ LeDoux told the newspaper. â€œOld news.â€ Officials at the National Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer, Alaska, began calling off tsunami advisories and warnings after a wave of less than 1 foot (30 centimeters) was recorded in the community of Sand Point. â€œI might have expected a little bit more water, but Iâ€™m happy that there wasnâ€™t,â€ said David Hale, the senior duty scientist at the tsunami center. Tuesdayâ€™s quake was more powerful than the magnitude 7.1 earthquake that caused damage in the Anchorage area in November 2018. â€œThis earthquake released about 15 times as much energy as that earthquake, said West, the state seismologist. More than a dozen aftershocks of magnitude 4.0 or higher were reported immediately after the earthquake, he said from the Alaska Earthquake Center at the University of Alaska Fairbanks. â€We got people here who are going be working all night,â€ West said early Wednesday morning. â€These aftershocks will go and go and go and go.â€ The Alaska-Aleutian Trench was also where a magnitude 9.2 quake in 1964 was centered. That remains the second most powerful earthquake ever recorded. The temblor and ensuing tsunami caused widespread damage and killed 131 people, some as far away as Oregon and California. Alaska is the most actively seismic state. Nearly 25,000 earthquakes have been recorded in Alaska since Jan. 1, according to the center. Prosecutors plan to drop an involuntary manslaughter charge against Alec Baldwin in the fatal 2021 shooting of a cinematographer on the set of the Western film â€ Rust.â€ SpaceXâ€™s giant new rocket blasted off on its first test flight Thursday but exploded minutes after rising from the launch pad and crashed into the Gulf of Mexico. â€œThe truth matters. Lies have consequences,â€ said Dominion lawyer Justin Nelson in a news conference outside the courthouse after the announcement. Gunfire that erupted on busy highway in Maine is linked to a second crime scene where four people were found dead in a home. Oklahomaâ€™s governor is calling for the resignations of the four officials, one of whom also apparently made racist remarks in an audio recording. No people or satellites were aboard for this attempt. There wonâ€™t be another try until at least Wednesday. About 150 people walked at a Summerlin park on Sunday to raise awareness about antisemitism and to preserve the memory of the Holocaust.  In California and across the deserts of Arizona, there are flashes of color popping up after an unusually wet winter helped produce a so-called â€œSuperbloom.â€ A Massachusetts Air National Guard member was taken into custody Thursday in connection with the disclosure of highly classified military documents. Title: Strong earthquake prompts tsunami warning from Alaska Peninsula to western Kenai
Body: The tsunami warning originally stretched from the Alaska Peninsula to Kodiak Island and the western Kenai Peninsula, sending Alaskans scrambling to higher ground in communities such as Kodiak, Sand Point, Unalaska and Homer. Though some people in Anchorage received tsunami warning alerts, the Anchorage area was not at risk, said Louise Fode, warning coordination meteorologist with the National Weather Service. In its notice of the tsunami warning cancellation, the National Tsunami Warning Center said that â€œa tsunami was generated by this event, but no longer poses a threat. Some areas may continue to see small sea level changes.â€ The center also urged people not to return to hazard zones until local officials say it is safe to do so. James Gridley, director of the National Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer, said in an interview early Wednesday that â€œour procedures put us into a warning even if we havenâ€™t measured a tsunami wave â€” we imply that there is until we know better.â€   â€œThis is a very significant earthquake in size,â€ said Michael West, state seismologist with the Alaska Earthquake Center. The Tuesday night earthquake was â€œsomething like 15 times more energy than was released in the 2018 Anchorage earthquake,â€ he said. But since it happened offshore, there was much less shaking recorded, and West said earthquake center officials werenâ€™t expecting damage from shaking. The kind of earthquake that occurred Tuesday evening was typical for the southern coast of Alaska, West said. Itâ€™s also the same style â€” â€œmore or less,â€ West said â€” as the Great Alaska Earthquake of 1964. â€œThese are the style of earthquakes which can be very tsunami-producing,â€ West said. Vehicles stream from the Homer Spit after a tsunami warning sounded in Homer late Tuesday, July 21, 2020. (Pat Russell photo)  Kodiak residents gather at Kodiak High School late Tuesday, July 21, 2020, after a tsunami warning resulted from a magnitude 7.8 earthquake near Chignik. (Larry LeDoux photo)  In Kodiak, tsunami warning sirens sounded Tuesday night and residents headed to high ground. Kodiak High School opened its doors for evacuees, as did the local Catholic school. At Coast Guard base Kodiak, residents were instructed to head to Aviation Hill, high ground overlooking the nearby airport. The local public radio station reminded evacuees to carry masks. â€œWeâ€™ve got a high school full of people. Iâ€™ve been passing out masks since the first siren sounded,â€ said Larry LeDoux, superintendent of the Kodiak School District. â€Everythingâ€™s as calm as can be. Weâ€™ve got probably 300, 400 people all wearing masks,â€ he said.  At Kodiak High School, LeDoux said the sirens and evacuations were nothing out of the ordinary for someone who grew up in Kodiak. â€Iâ€™ve been doing these since I was a little kid,â€ he said. â€œOld news.â€ In the first minutes of a seismic event, there arenâ€™t usually enough ocean sensors to measure a tsunami wave, said Gridley with the National Tsunami Warning Center. You have to give it time to get to nearby sensors, he said, but if thereâ€™s a wave, beaches and shorelines could be impacted before then. â€œWe have to assume the worst case scenario,â€ Gridley said. â€œThe safest position is to get people moving.â€ Itâ€™s not like a hurricane that forms out in the ocean, days away from shore, he said â€” they have to go straight to a warning. Homer High School Principal Douglas Waclawski, left, stands at the entrance to the local high school while residents show up in search of higher ground in the early morning hours of Wednesday, July 22, 2020 in Homer, Alaska, after a powerful earthquake shook the region late Tuesday evening. (Megan Pacer/Homer Tribune via AP)  On Tuesday, the center issued its tsunami warning and kept the warning in place after seeing a 25-centimeter wave in Sand Point. Center officials knew the tsunami wouldnâ€™t be huge, Gridley said, but they had to be certain and wait for the entire wave cycle. â€œIf we just start seeing a little bump, we donâ€™t know if that bump is going to get much bigger, or if that was it,â€ Gridley said. After about an hour and a half Tuesday, the tsunami advisories for certain areas outside of the warning zones were canceled, Gridley said. â€œWe just had to wait long enough to see whether or not we would see more of a wave develop or not,â€ Gridley said. â€œAnd the answer was no.â€ The center canceled the tsunami warning, which grew to stretch from the Aleutian Islands to the Western Kenai, a little under two hours after it issued its initial warning. Unalaska City Manager Erin Reinders said the city activated its emergency operations center Tuesday night and notified the community to evacuate areas below 50 feet to higher ground, before later issuing the all-clear. â€We were in a (city) council meeting and started feeling it rocking, and by the time I got home from the council meeting then the warnings were going and had to turn back around,â€ Reinders said.  â€This is a developing situation, and we are monitoring closely the information that is coming from the state and federal agencies that weâ€™re collaborating with,â€ Ahlberg said before the tsunami warning was canceled. â€œSo at this juncture, Iâ€™m not putting a time stamp on it.â€ In Homer, sirens blared late Tuesday night, alerting residents to the tsunami threat. Tsunami warning announcements and sirens blare in Homer late Tuesday, July 21, 2020. (Tom Kizzia video)  According to Homer Deputy City Clerk and Deputy Public Information Officer Rachel Tussey, Homer residents were told to evacuate areas below 50 feet, and the city stood up an emergency operations center at the Homer Volunteer Fire Department. Tussey said the Homer High School was set up as an assembly point and emergency shelter.  â€œThe first wave didnâ€™t materialize, which is a great thing,â€ said Keeler, who had been in close contact with public safety staff in Sand Point since the earthquake. Sand Point residents gather after a tsunami warning late Tuesday, July 21, 2020.  (Sand Point Department of Public Safety)  The earthquake was felt in Sand Point, but there were no reports of major structural damage, Keeler said. A commercial fishing opener starting at 6 a.m. Wednesday means much of the substantial Sand Point fishing fleet has left the harbor for the fishing grounds, Keeler said.   â€œA rapidly receding or receded shoreline, unusual waves and sounds, and strong currents are signs of a tsunami,â€ the center said. â€œThe tsunami may appear as water moving rapidly out to sea, a gentle rising tide like flood with no breaking wave, as a series of breaking waves, or a frothy wall of water.â€ For the latest tsunami information, visit tsunami.gov. ADN staff members Morgan Krakow, James Brooks, Michelle Theriault Boots and Marc Lester contributed. 1 2 3 4 5 Â© 2023 Anchorage Daily News. All rights reserved.

Title: San Andreas Fault earthquake more likely after Ridgecrest quakes, scientists warn
Body:
This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten,
      or redistributed. Â©2023 FOX News Network, LLC. All rights reserved.
      Quotes displayed in real-time or delayed by at least 15 minutes. Market data provided by Factset. Powered and implemented by FactSet Digital Solutions. Legal Statement. Mutual Fund and ETF data provided by Refinitiv Lipper.
     Seismologist warns the event isn't over and it's possible there could be even a stronger earthquake on the way; Jeff Paul reports. Scientists have warned that last yearâ€™s Ridgecrest quakes in Southern California have increased the risk of a major San Andreas Fault earthquake. The quakes, warn catastrophe modeling company Temblor, have placed stress on the Garlock Fault that links the Ridgecrest Faults with the San Andreas Fault. In a blog post, Temblor CEO Ross Stein and Shinji Toda of Tohoku University explained thatÂ if the Garlock Fault ruptured in a large shock, â€œit would likely trigger a San Andreas earthquake north of Los Angeles.â€ A paper on the research has been published in the Bulletin of the Seismological Society of America. MAJOR SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA FAULT LINE EYED AFTER STUDY SHOWS UNPRECEDENTED MOVEMENT â€œIn our study, we developed a new method to forecast future seismicity,â€ Stein and Toda wroteÂ in the post. â€œThese forecasts are not earthquake predictions, which have so far proven impossible. Rather, they are probabilistic, framed in the language of chance. We use past seismicity, the stress imparted by recent large and moderate earthquakes and the equations governing how fault friction varies in time and space (â€˜rate-state frictionâ€™) to estimate the likelihood of future earthquakes of different sizes.â€ The 9.3-mile deep San Andreas Fault in California is one of the longest and most active in the world. This computer-generated image is enhanced to show its features - illustration. (SRTM, JPL, NASA) The experts used machine learning technology in their analysis, which estimates a 2.3 percent chance of a magnitude-7.7 Garlock Fault rupture in the next year. â€œThis is 100 times higher than its annual chances in the â€˜UCERF3â€™ benchmark model for California, which is jointly issued by the [U.S. Geological Survey], the Southern California Earthquake Center, and the California Geological Survey,â€ Stein and Toda wrote. The scientists calculate thatÂ if the Garlock Fault ruptured to within about 30 miles of its junction with the San Andreas Fault, â€œit would raise the probability of a San Andreas rupture extending to the southeast, on the so-called â€˜Mojave section,â€™ by a factor of about 150.â€  â€œThat translates into a 50/50 chance of a San Andreas Mojave section rupture (with a range, 25 percent-67 percent), either immediately following a Garlock quake, or after some delay,â€ they added. Part of the visible section of the San Andreas Fault. (AP) Set against this backdrop, they estimate that the net chance of a large San Andreas earthquake in the next 12 months is 1.15 percent. â€œWhile small, this probability is 3.5-5.0 times higher than the annual chance of a large San Andreas earthquake in the â€˜UCERF3â€™ benchmark model for California,â€ they added. Given the small likelihood of a large San Andreas earthquake in the next year, the scientists say no one should panic. â€œBut, as we have seen during the COVID-19 pandemic, low probability chain-reaction events do occur in nature, and when they do, their consequences can be great,â€ they explained. â€œIt is the responsibility of scientists to assess the likelihood of such events, and then to bring them to the attention of the public and decision-makers.â€ CLICK HERE TO GET THE FOX NEWS APP Seismologist Lucy Jones, who was not involved in the study, described the analysis as â€œelegantâ€ in a tweet, but added that it â€œassumes a reason for quake triggering that is not consensus.â€ â€œThe possibility of a San Andreas quake AT ANY TIME should already be part of your planning or you shouldn't be in California,â€ she wrote, in another tweet. Follow James Rogers on TwitterÂ @jamesjrogers Get a daily look at whatâ€™s developing in science and technology throughout the world. Subscribed You've successfully subscribed to this newsletter!

Title: Powerful earthquake shakes southern Mexico, at least 4 dead
Body: By MARÃA VERZA and CHRISTOPHER SHERMAN Associated Press MEXICO CITY (AP) â€” A powerful earthquake centered near the southern Mexico resort of Huatulco killed at least four people, swayed buildings in Mexico City and sent thousands fleeing into the streets. Mexico President AndrÃ©s Manuel LÃ³pez Obrador said one person was killed and another injured in a building collapse in Huatulco, Oaxaca. Otherwise he said reports were of minor damage from the magnitude 7.4 quake, including broken windows and collapsed walls. Oaxaca Gov. Alejandro Murat later said a second person was killed in an apparent house collapse in the tiny mountain village of San Juan Ozolotepec.  Pemex also said the quake caused a fire at its refinery in the Pacific coast city of Salina Cruz, relatively near the epicenter. It said one worker was injured and the flames were quickly extinguished. Churches, bridges and highways also suffered damage during the quake. LÃ³pez Obrador said there had been more than 140 aftershocks, most of them small. Seismic alarms sounded midmorning with enough warning for residents to exit buildings. Power was knocked out to some areas. Helicopters flew over downtown Mexico City and police patrols sounded their sirens. Groups of people still milled around in close proximity on streets and sidewalks in some neighborhoods of the capital about an hour after the quake. Many were not wearing masks despite past appeals from municipal officials for them to do so as a way to curb the spread of the new coronavirus. Inside a Mexico City military barracks converted to COVID-19 hospital, medical staff suited in protective equipment tried to calm anxious patients. Unable to evacuate isolation areas, patients huddled under a large beam in the womenâ€™s ward while a nurse tried to calm one having a panic attack. Teresa JuÃ¡rez could only wish for it to pass quickly from her hospital bed where she lay connected to oxygen. Diabetic and with high blood pressure, JuÃ¡rez said she thought about her five children. â€œItâ€™s horrible, youâ€™re here and you donâ€™t know what to do,â€ she said.  It was felt in Guatemala and throughout south and central Mexico. In Huatulco, a laid-back beach destination known for surfing and small protected coves, the earthquake knocked goods off shelves and some rubble from buildings. Mari GonzÃ¡lez of the Princess Mayev hotel in Huatulco said staff and guests were able to evacuate the building before the quake, but that 45 minutes after the initial quake they were still outside as strong aftershocks continued. â€œIt was strong, very strong,â€ she said. GonzÃ¡lez said there was some visible broken glass and mirrors, but no major damage. The staff was waiting for the aftershocks to dissipate before fully evaluating the property. Local news media reported damage to some buildings in the state capital, Oaxaca city. State officials said they were looking for damage. The USGS estimated that some 2 million people felt strong or moderate shaking and another 49 million felt weak or light shaking. The earthquake hit a quake-prone region where four underground tectonic plates come together. In the past 35 years, there have been at least seven magnitude 7 or greater earthquakes, killing around 10,000 people â€” most of them in a 1985 8.0 quake. â€œThis has the potential to be a deadly earthquake and cause significant damage,â€ U.S. Geological Survey seismologist Paul Earle said. â€œThis area is capable of and has had larger earthquakes in the past.â€ â€œThere will be aftershocks,â€ Earle said. â€œIt is not unexpected to see a magnitude 6 at this point and a number of smaller ones.â€ This quake happened when the Cocos plate, which is to the southwest of the area, slipped under the North American plate, Earle said. â€œYouâ€™ve got all sorts of plates and theyâ€™re moving quickly,â€ Earle said. â€œThe important thing is how fast the plates are moving relative to each other.â€ The U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration forecast a tsunami threat with waves three to 10 feet above tide levels along parts of the coasts of Mexico. Smaller waves were expected through Central America, Peru and Ecuador. Guatemalaâ€™s national disaster agency issued a tsunami alert for its southern Pacific coast forecasting the arrival of waves up to a meter high. It advised people to move away from the sea. __ Associated Press writers Chris Torchia in Mexico City and Seth Borenstein in Washington contributed to this report. Copyright 2020 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed without permission.

Title: 7.4 magnitude earthquake hits southern Mexico
Body:
KFOR.com Oklahoma City Please enter a search term. Please enter a search term. A 7.4 magnitude earthquake occurred June 23, 2020 along the southern coastline of Mexico.   A 7.4 magnitude earthquake occurred June 23, 2020 along the southern coastline of Mexico.   MEXICO (CNN) â€” At least two people have died after a 7.4 magnitude earthquake hit Mexicoâ€™s southern coastline on Tuesday, collapsing buildings and prompting evacuations.  Oaxacaâ€™s state governor Alejandro Murat said a 22-year-old woman and a man were among the dead. The Oaxacan Health Services also reported damages from the quake to general hospitals in Pochutla, Puerto Escondido and Pinotepa Nacional and a few community hospitals in other areas. According to Murat, two of the hospitals with damages have been dealing with coronavirus patients. â€œWe are verifying [damages] because this hospital is also tending Covid cases on the Oaxacan coast,â€ he said on a radio interview with Radio FÃ³rmula. The severity of the damages are not specified. Mexicoâ€™s National Coordination of Civil Protection reported the first death after a structure collapsed after the earthquake, which occurred just east of the popular tourist destination Huatulco. Authorities also reported a power outage throughout the stateâ€™s capital and damages to the exterior of a hospital in Oaxaca. The earthquake could be felt as far as Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador. In capital Mexico City, approximately 190 miles north of the epicenter, tremors were felt and sirens were heard wailing. Tsunami waves of 0.68 meters (2.2 ft) were observed in Acapulco and 0.71 meters (2.3 ft) in Salina Cru. An earlier tsunami warning was revised down, according to the US Tsunami Warning System, forecasting possible waves of up to a meter (3.3 ft). The damage in Oaxaca state is considered light to moderate, according to the US Geological Survey (USGS) ShakeMap. Estimates modeled by the USGS suggest that localized casualties and damage are possible but there are likely to be fewer than 100 fatalities and less than $100 million in damage. However, the model only includes earthquake shaking, and not any impacts from potential tsunamis on the coastline. The USGS said that recent earthquakes in the area have caused secondary hazards such as tsunamis and landslides. Earlier estimates put the magnitude of the earthquake at 7.7, but that has been revised down to 7.4 (and additional revisions are possible). Mexico is one of the worldâ€™s most seismically active regions and has a long history of devastating earthquakes. The country is located on top of three large tectonic plates and their movement causes regular quakes and occasional volcanic eruptions. In 2017, two powerful earthquakes hit the country in two weeks, toppling buildings, cracking highways and killing hundreds of people. One had a magnitude of 7.1 and the other a magnitude of 8.1. Mexico City is particularly vulnerable to earthquakes because its very soft and wet ground amplifies shaking and is prone to liquefaction, in which dirt transforms into a dense liquid when sufficiently churned.

Body: Share  Saturday night's quake was the largest recorded earthquake in Oklahoma since a magnitude 4.4 quake in May 2019.Thousands of earthquakes have been recorded in Oklahoma in recent years, with many linked to the underground injection of wastewater from oil and gas production.Regulators have directed producers to close some injection wells.The Associated Press contributed to this report. Title: Earthquake Strikes Oklahoma, Felt Around Tulsa After Trump Rally
Body: An earthquake in northern Oklahoma struck the entire state, including in Tulsa shortly after President Donald Trump finished his comeback rally before thousands of supporters.  USGS preliminary report has upgraded the earthquake to a 4.5 magnitude 5.6 miles northwest of Perry, OK. #okquake #okwx â€” NWS Tulsa (@NWStulsa) June 21, 2020 Residents in Oklahoma City, Enid, Stillwater, and Ponca City all reported shaking, according to the USGS. KOKH reported that more than 200 people reported the earthquake to the USGS. The National Weather Service (NWS) office in Tulsa said it felt a tremor on Saturday night, and the earthquake made waves on social media after Trumpâ€™s visit to the state. Just felt an earthquake here at the NWS Tulsa Office! â€” NWS Tulsa (@NWStulsa) June 21, 2020  In other news, there was just a 4.2 earthquake about 70 miles from Tulsa. Oklahoma has had a surge of quakes the past decade due to fracking. Just a reminder that aside from his utter failure in response to covid and racial injustice, Trump has atrociously failed the environment. â€” Beau Willimon (@BeauWillimon) June 21, 2020 Earthifa ğŸ˜¹ğŸ˜¹ğŸ˜¹ â€” Simon Curtis (@simoncurtis) June 21, 2020 Saturday nightâ€™s earthquake was the largest recorded earthquake in Oklahoma since May 2019, when the state experienced a 4.4 magnitude quake. Thousands of earthquakes have taken place in Oklahoma in recent years, with many linked to fracking, a process used for extracting oil and gas. Body:

SAN DIEGO (CNS) â€“ A magnitude 3.1 earthquake east of Temecula Monday rattled parts of southern Riverside County and the San Diego area but caused no reported damage or injuries.  People felt the shaker in various Coachella Valley cities, as well as in Menifee, Escondido, Lakeside, Ramona and San Diego, according to the USGS. Title: Solving the virus and earthquake, Magna-style
Body: Brandis Touhuni stands in front of the pet-grooming business she owns on Magna Main Street. The March 18, 2020, earthquake shut her business down for just three days. Lee Benson, Deseret News  MAGNA â€”Â Want to see resilience? Want to see getting right back up after taking a punch? Want to see not waiting for the government to take care of it for you? You could do worse than walk into Aunt Ernieâ€™s Pet Parlor on Magnaâ€™s Main Street and talk to Brandis Touhuni. Brandis, 39, owns Aunt Ernieâ€™s, a dog grooming business (the name pays tribute to the grooming skills of Brandisâ€™ mother, Ernestine) that is located near the west end of Main below the big â€œCâ€ on the mountain â€” for Cyprus High School â€” and the beginning of the Kennecott Copper property that for over 100 years has defined the town. Magna started out, and remains, a minerâ€™s town, a hard-working, no-nonsense, get the shift done and then hope for a little overtime kind of place. A pandemic and earthquake do not appear to have changed that. Itâ€™s been almost two months since Magna got its chamber of commerce nightmare. First, on March 11, came the coronavirus pandemic. Second, on March 18, came a 5.7 earthquake, the epicenter less than 4 miles northeast of downtown Magna and its century-old buildings. While damage was reported throughout the Salt Lake Valley, Magna got the worst of it. Whatâ€™s transpired ever since, in Brandisâ€™ view from west Main, has been vintage Magna. â€œPeople have come together. Thereâ€™s a small-town feel here youâ€™re not going to find a lot of other places,â€ she says. â€œEveryoneâ€™s always helping each other.â€ She uses herself as exhibit one. This 104-year-old building on Magna Main Street owned by James and Brandis Touhuni suffered extensive damage in the March 18, 2020, earthquake. Brandis Touhuni Brandis Touhuni works behind the counter of Aunt Ernieâ€™s, the pet grooming business she owns on Magnaâ€™s Main Street. Lee Benson, Deseret News This 104-year-old building on Magna Main Street owned by James and Brandis Touhuni suffered extensive damage in the March 18, 2020, earthquake. Lee Benson, Deseret News  But then they got in the car to check on the two 104-year-old buildings they own on Main Street. (Both buildings, by the way, were used in the Disney TV show â€œAndi Mackâ€ when it was filmed on location in Magna. Aunt Ernieâ€™s was the Spoon Diner and the building next door was a record shop). The Aunt Ernieâ€™s building had some cracks in the interior that didnâ€™t appear to be too serious, but the building next door was in shambles, with bricks littered everywhere, facing major repair. Like most everyone else in Magna, the Touhuniâ€™s didnâ€™t have earthquake insurance. So what did they do? Call a lawyer and take out bankruptcy? Sit down and cry? Nope. They started rebuilding immediately. And their neighbors immediately pitched in to help. â€œWe had three separate fundraisers for us before we knew it,â€ says Brandis. â€œWe got help from people we didnâ€™t even know.â€ The response was welcome, but it wasnâ€™t unexpected. Itâ€™s why Brandis and James live in Magna. They both grew up here, both went to Cyprus High, both have Magna in their veins. â€œItâ€™s a good town, a really good place to live,â€ says Brandis. â€œIt doesnâ€™t always have the best of reputations. Itâ€™s a low-income area, so youâ€™ve got some drug problems and some things like that. But the majority are just good, solid blue-collar people who would do anything for you. Maybe they ended up here on the west side because itâ€™s what they could afford â€” but they stay because they want to. â€œI mean weâ€™re tough out here. Weâ€™ve all had to work and bust our butts for what we have and I donâ€™t think anybodyâ€™s willing to just give it up. Thereâ€™s not a business owner down here thatâ€™s not willing to fight for what theyâ€™ve put their heart and soul into.â€ Bureaucratic restrictions and red tape that are part and parcel of pandemics and earthquakes have just been additional hurdles to clear. â€œThey (the government) have done nothing but make it more difficult,â€ says Brandis. â€œThe hoops weâ€™ve had to jump through with Salt Lake County have been ridiculous.â€ As an example, after the earthquake the county turned off the gas to all the buildings. It was a safety measure and completely understandable. The problem was, no one from the county returned to turn the gas back on, and the gas company wouldnâ€™t do it because it didnâ€™t turn it off. â€œSo we took a wrench and turned ours back on ourselves,â€ says Brandis. â€œThe other businesses were like, â€˜How did you get your gas back on?â€™ And weâ€™re like, â€˜With a wrench,â€™ and theyâ€™re like, â€˜Weâ€™re going to do that, too.â€™ And we all high-fived.â€ Problem-solving, Magna style.
